titleStmt.author: Dickens, Charles, 1812-1870.

availability.p: © This work is the property of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. It may be used freely by individuals for research, teaching and personal use as long as this statement of availability is included in the text.

publicationStmt.publisher: Published in a Limited Edition by J. A. Hill & Company

notesStmt.note: Call number Dickens 135 Folio (Rare Book Collection, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill)

editorialDecl.p: The text has been entered using double-keying and verified against the original. The text has been encoded using the recommendations for Level 4 of the TEI in Libraries Guidelines.
Original grammar, punctuation, and spelling have been preserved. Encountered typographical errors have been preserved, and appear in red type.
Any hyphens occurring in line breaks have been removed, and the trailing part of a word has been joined to the preceding line.
All quotation marks, em dashes and ampersand have been transcribed as entity references.
All double right and left quotation marks are encoded as ” and “ respectively.
All single right and left quotation marks are encoded as ’ and ‘ respectively.
All em dashes are encoded as —
Indentation in lines has not been preserved.
Spell-check and verification made against printed text using Author/Editor (SoftQuad) and Microsoft Word spell check programs.

revisionDesc.change: Jill Kuhn Sexton finished TEI-conformant encoding and final proofing.
Apex Data Services, Inc. finished transcribing the text.

docImprint.publisher:
Published in a Limited Edition by
J. A. HILL & COMPANY

div.head:
Dickens Portfolio
PART I
CHARLES DICKENS

Dickens Portfolio
PART II
DAVID COPPERFIELD

figure.p: David's munificent order at the public house.

David and Steerforth arrive unexpectedly at Mr. Peggotty's
fireside.
Steerforth shows up Mr. Mell “as a beggar.”
David and Dora invite Traddles to dinner.
Traddles, as Mr. Burke, or Mr. Pitt, would deliver withering denunciations of the corruption of my aunt and Mr. Dick, while I, note-book on knee, fagged after him with all my might and main.
David bears ill tidings to Steerforth's mother and Rosa.
Peggotty returns after a vain search for Emily.
Mr. Micawber delivers some valedictory remarks.

David and his guests become the meekest of the meek before
Steerforth's respectable serving man.
Uriah Heap obtrudes himself on David at the dinner party.
David makes himself known to his aunt.
Little David is hospitably received by Mr. Peggotty.

div.head:
Dickens Portfolio
PART III
OLD CURIOSITY SHOP

figure.p: Quilp, amiable as usual, surprises his wife's visitors.
Mrs. Jarley taking tea on the head of a drum.
He (the old man) sat so wild and restless, so feverishly anxious, so ravenous for the paltry stakes, that she could have almost better borne to see him dead.
At the Punch and Judy show.
Quilp passes the time pleasantly with his friends.
Flight of Nell and her grandfather.

div.head:
Dickens Portfolio
PART IV
DOMBEY AND SON

figure.p:
Dr. Blimber's young gentlemen as they appeared when enjoying
themselves.

Major Bagstock is delighted to have the opportunity, and Cleopatra
is gracious.

“Plain Joe, sir — Joey B. — Josh. Bagstock — Joseph — rough
and tough old J., sir. At your service.”
Mr. Dombey stoops low to get secret intelligence.
Miss Tox introduces the party to fill the vacancy.
Mr. Carker, abstracted, is watched by vengeful eyes.
Mr. Carker in his hour of triumph.
The Wooden Midshipman greets Florence and Miss Nipper.

div.head:
Dickens Portfolio
PART V
LITTLE DORRIT

figure.p: The Father of the Marshalsea leaves it in state.
Little Mother tells Maggie the story of the Princess.
The Father of the Marshalsea entertains a pensioner at tea.
Little Dorrit and her sister find their uncle playing the clarionet.

Frederick electrifies his brother by taking up the cudgels for
Little Dorrit.

Affery hears the mysterious noises again, to the indignation of
her virtuous husband.

div.head:
Dickens Portfolio
PART VI
BARNABY RUDGE

figure.p: Barnaby and his father meet at last.
Solomon Daisy has seen the ghost of a murdered man.
Barnaby joins the ranks of Lord George Gordon.
Barnaby's mother at the Warren after an absence of 22 years.
Mr. Chester goes off jauntily in his chair.
Hugh sleeping on the bench of the Maypole Inn.
A mysterious stranger disturbs the cronies at the Maypole Inn.
Dennis and Hugh drink to the health of Lord George Gordon.
Mr. Chester makes himself agreeable to Mrs. Varden.
“A fine old country gentleman” is diverted by Grip.
The blind man terrifies Barnaby's mother.

div.head:
Dickens Portfolio
PART VII
BLEAK HOUSE

figure.p: “We have among us . . . a brother and a boy. Devoid of relations, devoid of flocks and herds, devoid of gold and silver and of precious stones.” — Mr. Chadband.
Mr. Bucket is made welcome at Mrs. Bagnet's birthday party.

Miss Flite explains that she attends court regularly and expects
a judgment — “on the Day of Judgment.”

Mr. Tulkinghorn and the “young man of the name of Guppy”
have an audience with Lady Dedlock.
Dame Durden gets her first love token.
Tom-all-Alone's. — It might be better that the sun should sometimes set upon the British dominions than that it should rise upon so vile a wonder.

Mr. Guppy offers his heart, his income, and a mother-in-law,
and is rejected.

div.head:
Dickens Portfolio
PART VIII
MARTIN CHUZZLEWIT

figure.p: Meekness of Mr. Pecksniff and his charming daughters.

“I wish they wos still abed,” said the boy. “They're very
noisy abed all calling for their boots.”

Mr. Pecksniff and his younger daughter comfort the wounded
orphan.

Mrs. Gamp rose — morally and physically rose — and denounced
Mrs. Prig.

The charity children are admonished to grow up Pecksniffs,
and Martin is much gratified by an imposing ceremony.

Mr. Moddle is led to the contemplation of his destiny by Miss
Charity.
Tom Pinch and Martin on a social occasion.
Pecksniff hears some truths and Tom Pinch loses an idol.

The Board of the Anglo-Bengalee Disinterested Loan and Life
Insurance Company.

“What do you mean by flopping yourself down and praying
agin me? What do you suppose the worth of your prayers
may be?”—Jerry Cruncher.

“I don't forget you, my soul, and never shall, and never can,”
said Mantalini.
Sam Weller's father and his son.

Away they all went, twenty couple at once; hands half round
and back again the other way, down the middle and up again.

“Bob had been Tim's blood horse all the way from church,
and had come home rampant.”
The Bird of Prey brought down.
The Evil Genius of the House of Boffin.

Rogue Riderhood, narrowly saved from drowning, becomes his
old surly self again.
Mr. Wegg prepares a grindstone for Mr. Boffin's nose.
